Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2009 09:42AM Faith316 wrote: The CT scan was really quick.  Can't recall exactly how long, but no more than 5 minutes at most and I actually don't think it was even that long.  The simulation was no big deal at all.  The techs were in there right beside me the whole time and it took very little time.  Nowhere near the 40 plus minutes that LJ13-2 had.  I don't think it was more than 15 minutes.  They just put a few small Xs  on me with a blue sharpie.  I, too, am very claustrophobic and hate MRIs.  But, my radiation treatments did not cause me any claustrophobia.  I was never enclosed in any way.  The machine had an arm that kind of rotated around me but it didn't get close to me and I never felt closed in at all.  It was quick.  I think each rads treatment only took about 12 minutes and probably 3 or 4 of those were getting me lined up correctly on the table. Trust me.  I am REALLY claustrophobic but found the rads simulation and actual rads treatments to be easy.  If I can do it, anybody can.  Hope this eases your mind some.  The unknown is the worst part.  You will be fine.

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2011 02:52PM Faith316 wrote: My lumpectomy and SNB was uneventful.  No pain afterwards.  I never needed to take any pain meds, not even Tylenol.  I felt really good within days.  The drain stayed in about a week.  That was probably the biggest nuisance of the whole thing.  I'm very fair-skinned and did have burns during the  last couple of weeks of radiation, but it healed up quickly.  I used something called Silvadene and it really took care of the burns. I can't imagine that you wouldn't be just fine to take a vacation a month later.  A year after I had my lumpectomy, I had a recurrence and had to have an excisional biopsy which basically was just another lumpectomy as she took pretty much just as much tissue as she had the first time.  (Only difference was I had no SNB that time.)  I had the surgery one day and the next day, drove 500 miles by myself to visit a friend in another state.  Good luck to you.  It will be much easier than you think.

Posts.Content: Faith316 wrote: I had lumpectomy, AC and Taxol and Herceptin and then 30 rads treatment with my first BC dx.  I ended up having a second dx as IBC which started while on chemo and during rads for the first dx which was IDC. Referred to MD Anderson.  They changed my chemo and I did two new drugs for 6 months and then had a uni-mx in February.  I did not heal very well.  Incision took longer than normal to totally heal.  Also, I have lots of adhesions in my chest and underarm area down my side to underneath where I have that dreaded "dog-ear" that many of us end up with after mx.  When I stretch my arm upward, all along my side really pulls and you can see this elongated thick band stick out.  The skin on my chest is adhered to the chest wall.  My physical therapist says that most of her post-mx patients don't look near as bad as me.  She said that the type of problems I am having with the adhesions and skin stuck to the chest wall are similar to the type of things burn patients have.  She said it is almost like I need to have surgery to release some of the adhesions, but another surgery would mean --- you guessed it -- even more scar tissue to adhere! My surgeon says that most surgeons really don't like to do surgery on people who have had previous rads because they don't know how well they will heal.  My doctors wanted me to wait to have reconstruction since I have had cancer twice now in two years with the latest being IBC -- so aggressive and likely to recur.  I don't know when they will say ok for me to have the DIEP surgery.  But, after the way I healed after mx, makes me wonder if I should even have another surgery. Anybody else have mx after previously having rads and if so, did you have any of the same type of issues I am having? Thanks in advance for any replies. Posts.Content: Faith316 wrote: I am a teacher and trying to decide whether to apply for disability retirement.  I was first dx. with IDC in 4/08.  Had lumpectomy, axillary node dissection with 2/8 nodes positive, AC x 4, 12 weekly Taxol with concurrent Herceptin and then 30 rads tx.  During my radiation, I presented with symptoms of IBC but all my doctors said it had to be side effects from radiation.  It was debated from about 3/09-6/09 when I finally convinced them to biopsy it, and it was IBC.  So, all my chemo and rads had been totally ineffective.  I was referred to MD Anderson and my onc there stopped the Herceptin (which I had been on for 9 months at that point) and switched me to Tykerb and Xeloda which immediately began working.  A month later my IBC rash was gone and all the other syptoms abating.  I stayed on both T and X for 6 months and stopped the Xeloda in 1/10 right before my uni-mx and another node dissection.  Pathology on all of that shows NED.  But, I remain on Tykerb to this day --- 27 months so far.  My local onc wants me to stay on Tykerb for 5 full years, but that is not definite.  Going to see what my MDA onc thinks.  I go back there in January. Although I have taken off at various times during this so far 3-1/2 year time period since my original dx, I am currently teaching (140 middle school kids).  I come home totally exhausted.  I feel weak a lot of the time and have the typical chronic diarrhea (from Tykerb) every day.  The fatigue is hard and working is just  wearing me out, but I am torn about what to do. My local dr says that because of it being recurrent, he considers me stage IV.  I know that an IBC dx is a pretty poor prognosis.  Everything I read (and I read a lot) says that only 25-50% of IBC patients will still be alive after 5 years.  I hope to be one of the lucky ones but only God knows. I am struggling with whether or not I want to apply for disability retirement or not.   I don't want to work up until the point that I am maybe really sick again and have no time to enjoy retirement but I also feel guilty considering doing this. Anybody else go through anything like this and have any advice for me?  I'd especially be interested in hearing from women who also take Tykerb but replies from any and all will be appreciated.  Anybody know how likely it is to get a disability retirement with a Stage IV IBC dx who is currently -- we *think* --- NED?  (Of course we are all just a scan away from that changing aren't we?) (Applying for it requires me to stop working for 6 months which would mean long term disability again and then possibly being denied.  If denied and have to go back to work, it would put me that much further from my 30 years to be eligible for retirement.  I currently have about 28 years in.   28 years seems so close to 30 when you read those numbers but the fact is that teaching for the rest of this year plus two more years is a lot of time. I am ready to not work but just not sure what to do.  Feel guilty if I quit but also don't want to regret not quitting sooner if I have a third recurrence.) Sorry for so long.  Thanks for taking the time to read. DX 4/08 IDC, ER-, PR-, HER2+, IIB, Grade 3,lumpectomy,2/8 nodes,4 AC,12 wks.Taxol,Herceptin,30 rads. DX IBC 6/09 while still in treatment. Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2012 06:39PM Faith316 wrote: Mine fell out towards the end of chemo and then for many approximately 3 month cycles they would fall out again or at least thin, but it was my eyelashes more noticeably than my eyebrows.  Everybody is always losing eyelash and eyebrow hairs, just not all at once so it isn't noticed.  But, when you lose them all at the same time, they are on the same regrowth cycle so you do notice it when they all fall out again at the same time.  Over time, the regrowth cycle gets more and more staggered and you don't notice it anymore.

Posts.Content: May 10, 2011 07:18PM Faith316 wrote: I did.  I took AC x 4, 12 weekly Taxol with concurrent Herceptin and 30 rads tx for my initial dx of IDC.  (Had lumpectomy and axillary node dissection with 2/8 nodes malignant.) While in the midst of my rads and while still on Herceptin, I was dx with IBC.  I went to MD Anderson Cancer Center and my onc there stopped the Herceptin and switched me to 6 months of Xeloda along with Tykerb.  After one day of being on these two new drugs, I saw improvement in my IBC rash.  Everyone thought, sure, wishful thinking on my part.  But, I was right and within a month, the rash was totally gone and all my other IBC symptoms were much improved.  I also had a PET/CT a month after being on the 2 drugs which showed me to be NED.  I stopped the Xeloda after 6 months and had a mx and another axillary node dissection.  Pathology showed no remaining cancer.  Stayed on the Tykerb and am still on it for 22 months now.  Still NED.  I was stage IIB with my IDC, but stage III with my IBC.  So, to answer your question --- yes, I had success with Xeloda (and Tykerb) at stage III.  Good luck to you

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2010 09:23AM - edited Jul 27, 2010 09:25AM by Faith316 When I was first diagnosed in April 2008, I cried and cried about the impending loss of hair.  At that time, it was the thing I dreaded the most.  I know that some  people go ahead and just cut their hair and get it over with.  My hair was long, half-way down my back, and I wanted to keep it as long as I could.  My oncologist could predict which week it would happen.  One day, combing it out after my shower, there were quite a few strands in my comb.  Next day, even more.  Same for the next day.  The following day, it was clumps and I knew it had to be cut that evening.  It was tough.  I stood there with tears running down my face as my husband cut it a section at a time and laid it on the table in front of me and then moved to another section. He then took a pair of clippers and got it as smooth as he could.  I then went outside and jumped in the pool.  After that, it actually wasn't that bad.  The anticipation of it happening was much worse than it actually happening.   Same for my mastectomy.  I dreaded it and cried, cried, cried.  But, after it was done, it was ok.  Getting dressed each day is no longer any big deal.  My body has changed, yes, but it is ok. (I had a lumpectomy with first diagnosis, and then mastectomy when I had a recurrence.)  It is now 2 years since my original diagnosis and 5 months since my mastectomy.  My hair is back and of course, not as long as it was, but really cute short.  My mastectomy has healed and even though I have to wait to have my reconstruction, (I had inflammatory breast cancer on my second diagnosis), it is ok.   The beginning of the breast cancer journey is the hardest part.  It will be ok.  These things will pass and you will do fine.  This forum is a wonderful support system no matter which part of the journey you are.  Whether it be learning about pathology reports, getting through surgery, dealing with chemo or radiation or hair falling out or growing in or ............ whatever part of the BC experience you are in the midst of, there are many, many women who have been through the same thing before you who will be there to help you, answer questions, and to support you. Good luck.  Stay around these boards and let all the people here help you get through this.  It will be ok.

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2010 12:04AM Faith316 wrote: Regarding eyelashes --- It is pretty common for eyelashes and even eyebrows to fall out again several months after your chemo is over.  People normally lose eyelashes and hair from your brows all the time.  But, when you take chemo and lose them all at once, they then all come back in again at the same time and thus are on the same growth/shed cycle.  It sometimes takes awhile for them to kind of "randomize" the cycle and not fall out at once. Mine fell out twice after Taxol ended.  Now they are back to normal. I'm sorry I can't help with #2 and #3.

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2010 08:04PM - edited Jun 8, 2010 07:44AM by Faith316 Original dx was 4/08 and did 6 months of chemo followed by radiation and continuing Herceptin  treatments which were to last until Sept. 2009.  But, while still taking Herceptin and in the middle of radiation, I had a recurrence but this time it came back as IBC.  (My first dx was IDC.)  So, Herceptin stopped after my infusion in July 2009.  They changed me to oral daily chemo since that time.  So, I have not had any further infusions, but have opted to keep my port, for now at least, for several reasons. -- it doesn't bother me -- my recovery from port surgery was horrible, much worse for me than any of my biopsies, lumpectomy or even my mastectomy.  Lots of pain. -- I have already had a recurrence while still in treatment, so although I am hopeful that it is gone this time, I don't want to have to have port insertion surgery to recover from if it comes back again.  (And, since I most recently had Her2 +  inflammatory breast cancer, I know my chance of another recurrence is pretty high especially in the next few years.) -- In February when I had my mastectomy, they couldn't get an IV in my arm after numerous tries so they put it in my port.  I was glad that day that I still had it. I do have to have it flushed monthly but to me, that is no big deal.  I have to go monthly for bloodwork anyways so I'd be having to go to my doctor's office regardless.  They can flush it and do a blood draw at the same time. I may change my mind at some point and have it removed but not just yet.

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2010 07:09AM - edited Jun 1, 2010 07:13AM by Faith316 nine_rugrats, My side effects from Tykerb honestly aren't too bad.  I've been on Tykerb for approaching one year now.  (Started in July 2009.)  For the first 6 months, I took Xeloda also.  I was on 4500mg daily of Xeloda and 1250 mg daily of Tykerb.  I briefly had the rash (like acne on my face) when I first started.  Used Clindamycin gel and it cleared up within probabably a month.  I also had LOTS of diarrhea and big time hand/foot syndrome.  After 6 months, I stopped the Xeloda and increased the Tykerb to 1500 mg daily which is what I am still taking.  The h/f syndrom improved 99%.  I only occasionally get a split on the hands or feet instead of having them constantly like I did before.  I do now have the rash/acne thing going on again and have for about the past maybe 3 months.  Still using the Clindamycin and it keeps it from getting out of control.  I do have some diarrhea still but I'm almost certain that is more from my diabetes medicine I take called Metformin because on days where I forget to take the Metformin, I don't have a problem. So, long story short -- for me, other than the inconvenience and aggravation at times of the rash/acne thing (it even gets on my scalp some), the Tykerb for me isn't that bad.  I hate it when I hear how it makes some women have lots of problems and i feel fortunate that for me it does not.  It (along with the Xeloda, although my doctor thinks mostly the Tykerb) has worked for me.  So, to answer your question, not all women have a terrible time with it.  If you have to take it, I hope you do well with it.

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2011 03:13PM - edited Nov 13, 2011 03:14PM by Faith316 Try taking some ibuprofen (Advil or Motrin) to see if it will relieve the inflammation and maybe the pain.  Tylenol is not an NSAID and thus won't help inflammation like ibuprofen will.  If he thinks it is an infection, why did he not prescribe an antibioitic for you?  It probably is not BC, but it is false to say that BC does not have pain unless it is an advanced stage.  Some BC causes pain, some does not.  There is no rule about that.  You definitely need to talk to your doctor again tomorrow.  Good luck and keep us posted how things are going.

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2009 04:17PM - edited Dec 16, 2009 10:31PM by Faith316 Good post for you from Binney.  Just to echo my thoughts.  It is doable.  When I was first diagnosed, I assumed the chemo would make me horribly sick and I would be in bed and not able to do my regular things.  None of that turned out to be true.  I was never sick one time with any of my chemo treatments.  Felt queasy sometimes but have never thrown up.  I still did pretty much whatever I wanted to do, went shopping, went on vacations, etc.  Yes, I lost my long hair and that was hard, but I quickly adapted to throwing on a ballcap.  Never bothered with a wig because I knew I'd be hot and uncomfortable with a wig on but many women do wear one.  It wasn't long before my hair started coming back in.  I tried to go to stores when they would be less crowded, went to the beach in October instead of busy July and washed my hands a lot.  I wish I had never had a BC diagnosis, but after getting started on my treatments, I learned that it wasn't as disruptive and horrible as I imagined it would be.  Hang in there and keep positive.  It probably won't be near as horrible as you are imagining right now.   Come here to this forum and ask questions as often as you like.  There is a wealth of information here and a lot of wonderful women who will help you and your mom get through this. Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2012 09:42PM Faith316 wrote: I am a really big girl and very claustrophobic but I can easily do a PET/CT.  It only takes about 25 minutes.  I do not feel really confined like I do in an MRI machine.  Not at all. I start with my head in the center of the machine but it isn't very far from the opening and I can easily see behind me and feel cool air.  The machine moves me backwards a few inches every 3 or 4 minutes so in a very short time, my head is out of the machine.  I always ask them to talk to me every few minutes to keep me informed on much time is left and that helps.  I do have to have my hands above my head, but that doesn't bother me.  They put a wedge under my knees so it isn't so hard on the back to lay there. I think I have had (if I am remembering correctly) 7 PET/CT scans and though I never look forward to them, they don't really bother me.  If I can do it, and I am REALLY claustrophobic, anybody can.  You'll do just fine!

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2010 10:38AM Faith316 wrote: Went to the podiatrist today after months of putting it off because I was afraid that it might really hurt!!!!  But, it did not.  The pain in my big toes was caused by ingrown nails compliments of Xeloda and Tykerb.  She numbed my toes by spraying something on it that would kind of freeze it.  Then she cut away the ingrown part.  It did not hurt at all and she was done within 5 minutes.  Then a bandaid with Neosporin and I was out the door.  She said that it would probably remedy the problem for 3 or 4 months and then I might need to have it done again.  But, now that I know that it is no big deal and that I worried needlessly, I won't hesitate to go back and have it done again if needed. So, if any of you are scaredy-cats like me and have put off going to a podatrist, I hope reading my account of my visit will help you be less anxious to go yourself.  I have been dealing with this for probably 9 months.  I wish I had gone sooner as it was no big deal and didn't hurt a bit.

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2009 06:23PM Faith316 wrote: Chemo was NOWHERE NEAR as hard as I imagined it would be.  I never really was sick.  I had some days where I didn't feel so great, but there weren't that many of them.  I NEVER threw up or even had that much nausea.  Yes, I lost my hair.  At the time, that was quite traumatic, but it grew back.  I was somewhat weak some times and didn't have as much energy, but usually felt plenty well enough to do most everything I wanted to do.  I didn't just stay home all the time.  I tried to avoid crowds of people and stayed well through my entire chemo treatments.  I think I might have had a cold once or twice, but that was it.  My hands and feet got sore, tingly and somewhat numb, I had some indigestion (Zantac took care of that), But, honestly, chemo was not that bad.  I would have the chemo if I were you.  You can get through it.  Right now, with no first-hand knowledge, I'm sure you are imaging the worst.  Most likely it won't be.  Chemo has come a long way!  Do any and everything you can to get rid of this disease once and for all.  Good luck.

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2010 01:05PM - edited Aug 19, 2013 10:47PM by Faith316 You just keep going.  I kind of felt the way you did at first.  When I was first diagnosed in April 2008 with IDC, I also had postive nodes, lymphovascular invasion, strongly HER2 positive, ER-, PR-, grade 3 poorly differentiated and a pretty big tumor at 3.1cm., stage IIB.   After my lumpectomy, I took Adriamycin, Cytoxin, Taxol and Herceptin.  I stayed on Herceptin and was in the middle of my 30 radiation treatments when I started showing signs of a different BC diagnosis ---- IBC.  All my doctors told me no way could I have another type of cancer after all the chemo and radiation I had undergone.  None of them had ever had a patient recur as IBC while still in active treatment.  But, when they finally did do a biopsy, I was right.  I did have IBC --stage 3C.  They referred me to MD Anderson to the inflammatory breast cancer program there.  My onc. there stopped my Herceptin and switched me to Xeloda and Tykerb and a month later, my PET/CT showed all clear.  So, after having had active cancer for 16 months and undergoing all those other drugs, I was finally clear.  That was in August 2009 and I have continued to be NED ever since. So --- even though everything about my case was always hitting me with bad news, the tide turned and I am now in remission.  Never lose hope.  Just take it one day at a time.  The hardest part is when you are first diagnosed and when you are waiting for treatment to start.  Once your treatment plan is in place, it gets easier and you don't think about BC 24 hours a day every day. Continue to hang out here on the forum and let the women here help you get through this.  Keep us posted how things are going.  Good luck.

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2009 01:59PM Faith316 wrote: I saw my breast surgeon first when I had my first dx which was IDC.  I didn't meet with my oncologist until after my  lumpectomy/axillary node dissection.  Now, with my current dx of IBC I was referred to MD Anderson.  I am finding out that many times they now prefer to use neo-adjuvant chemo before surgery in many different BC situations.  From what I understand, they are finding that some women do better with chemo before surgery who used to have it in the reverse order.  I suppose it depends on each woman's particular case.  So, I guess if I had it to over again, I would see my oncologist first.
